thread.title: Joe’s shock approach that could fix kick yips
thread.title_full: Joe’s shock approach that could fix kick yips

title: Joe’s shock approach that could fix kick yips
text:
Heppell to lead new era 0:36 Joe Daniher uses shock goalkicking approach at Essendon intra-club that could help fix kicking woes February 8, 2017 2:42pm @bjwaterworth Source: FOX SPORTS JOE Daniher’s set-shot goalkicking has been a source of great frustration for Essendon fans over recent years. 
But the emerging key forward might have found a new — and very unique — way to combat his kicking woes in front of goal. 
Daniher produced an unexpected approach to his set-shot routine during his impressive first-quarter intra-club display, before he was placed in cotton wool. 
Late in the first term of Wednesday’s match at Tullamarine, Daniher marked the ball around 40m out with little to no angle to deal with. In fact, if anything, he was positioned on the ideal side for a natural left-footer. 
But after going through his usual goalkicking routine, Daniher pulled a massive surprise when he unleashed a set-shot kick on his non-preferred right boot. 
While the kick wasn’t as graceful as a Nathan Buckley right boot, it ultimately produced the desired result, with the ball sailing through the goals just above mid-post height. 
It left the hundreds of onlookers at the club’s Tullamarine headquarters in shock. Joe Daniher flies for a mark over Kyle Langford at the club’s practice match. Picture: Wayne Ludbey Source: News Corp Australia 
HEPPELL UNVEILED AS BOMBERS’ NEW SKIPPER 
“I’ve got no comment,” a stunned Dons list manager Adrian Dodoro said on the club website’s broadcast. 
While Daniher underwent surgery on his left knee post-season, the right-foot attempt didn’t necessarily seem like an attempt to protect his injury, as he used his left foot on several occasions for field kicking and even snapping a behind. 
Essendon coach John Worsfold didn’t see the kick live, but hinted that it might have been a cheeky way to get some set-shot practice in. 
“He’s on a pretty strict rehab program looking after that knee,” Worsfold laughed. 
“I don’t know how far out he was, but he’s only supposed to be kicking over a certain distance — so maybe it was that. 
“He’s obviously been doing a lot of work on it, but he’s not supposed to have been kicking too much.” 
Daniher’s stunning right-foot kick wasn’t his only highlight for the term, with the big man taking a few strong marks and then spilling an attempt for the intra-club mark of the season contender. Joe Daniher is part of Essendon’s leadership group alongside Michael Hurley, Cale Hooker, Dyson Heppell, Zach Merrett, Jobe Watson and Brendon Goddard. Source: AAP 
He was then removed from the game just after quarter-time and moved onto the club’s second training ground — which has similar dimensions to Etihad Stadium — where he completed various run-throughs. 
“Joey’s tracking really well — we’re rapt,” Worsfold said. 
“His progression to be out there today — he was pretty excited about it. He doesn’t take long to slot in and look natural again.” 
It looks as a big season for the 22-year-old, who was on Wednesday announced as member of the club’s new-look leadership group led by Dyson Heppell. 
Daniher carried a heavy load for the Bombers in 2016, finishing with 43 goals for the season — 23 more than the next best fall in Mitch Brown. According to Champion Data , he has been targeted inside forward 50 on 429 occasions since 2013 — 252 more than any other player. 
Despite the responsibility for such a young player, his kicking for goal has constantly been scrutinised, particularly for his high ball drop and mid-kick rotation. 
His career goalkicking accuracy of 46.4 per cent is rated below average, with the AFL average sitting around 55.6 per cent. 
In an attempt to address his inaccuracy, Daniher tried several different goalkicking techniques last year, including the Steve Johnson-style approach where he turned 90 degrees and snapped for goal, even though he was directly in front at stages. 
Whether the right-foot kick was deliberate or simply an attempt to protect his left knee, it produced six points for his side. 
And there could be many more goals off his right boot to come this year. View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
